coredata.dc:title: Induced circular dichroism of azulene
coredata.dc:creator: Tajiri, Akio
Hirayama, Hidemi
Hatano, Masahiro
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The π→π* absorption bands of azulene show circular dichroism in the presence of (+)-nopinone.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 February 1980 INDUCED CIRCULAR DICHROISM OF AZULENE Akio TAJIRI, Hidemi HIRAYAMA and Masahiro HATANO Chemical Research Institute of Non-aqueous Solutions, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan Received 26 November 1979 The TT IT* absorption bands of azulene show circular dichroism m the presence of (+)-nopinone. 1. Introduction It is well known that optical activity is induced in achiral species in the presence ofchiral species, giving nse to induced circular dichroism (ICD) for the absorp- tion band of the achiral species As early as 1965, Mason et al. [1 ] observed the circular dichroism band for the d d transition of [Co(NH3)g] (€104)3 in aqueous di- ethyl-(+)-tartrate. They elucidated this induction effect to be due to outer-sphere coordination. ICD spectra have also been investigated by Bosnich et al. [2,3] not only for the d d transitions of [PtC^]2-, but also for the n -> ir* transitions ofbenzil and benzophenone in L-2,3-butanediol. Extensive studies on ICD have been carried out by Hay-ward et al- [4] for the n - - TT" transi- tions of symmetric and racemic aliphatic ketones in chiral tetrahydrofuranols. Noack [5] investigated the concentration dependence of ICD bands, and suggested the presence of the optically active 1 : 1 complex for the system with saturated ketones and 1-menthol While these experiments have so far been carried out in chiral media, Axelrod et al. [6], Bolard [7,8] and Hayward et al. (9,10] have measured the ICD bands for the n -> TT* transitions of carbonyl and nitro compounds in such solvents as CCl^ and CHgCN, with optically active sub- stances. Axelrod et al. [6] and Hayward et al. [9,10] concluded from. their work that specific bonding, for example hydrogen bonding between optically inactive and active species, is not a pre-requisite to ICD, but ICD may appear m a system in which chiral and achiral species are assumed to be completely dissociated and interact through long-range van der Waals or dispersion forces. Schipper and Norden [11] have discussed dispersion induced circular dichroism (DICD) for magnetic dipole- allowed transitions of achiral molecules through the magnetic transition moment. As described above, ICD is quite a general phenomen in the presence of chiral species. However, ICD studies have so far been limited to the d d and n - IT* transi- tions which are electrically forbidden but magnetically allowed. We report here ICD for the electrically allowed n -> TT * transitions of azulene. 2. Experimental Azulene of high purity is commercially available and was used without further purification. (+)-nopmone was carefully distilled several times under reduced pres- sure, and checked with respect to [a] p (found: +18 0 , literature. +18.4 ). The UV and MCD spectra of (+)- nopinone at room temperature are shown in fig. 1 Spectrograde cyclohexane was used as solvent, without further purification. Spectroscopic measurements were carried out by varying the concentration of (+)-nopinone while keeping that of azulene constant, using a Hitachi EPS-3T record- ing photometer and a JASCO J-20A recording polamn- eter for the UV and CD runs Molar ellipticity [0] (deg mol~1 cm2) was calculated as if it referred to azulene alone. 22 Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 February 1980 " s " an S 300 350 400 iUnnil n-4 Fig 2. Induced circular dichroism of azulene (5.0 X 10 Nf) and (+)-nopinone (0.1 M) in cyclohexane at room temperature. 320 3X0 TUnml Fig 1 - The UV (bottom) and CD (top) spectra of (+)-nopinone m cyclohexane at room temperature. 3. Results and discussion Although (+)-nopinone shows no CD in the wave- length region longer than 320 nm, as seen from fig. 1, m the wavelength region of 350 400 nm we see a new positive CD band in fig- 2. The concentration was 0.1 M for (+)-nopinone and 5.0 X 10~4 M for azu- lene. The new CD band has not been detected at a con- centration ofnopmone lower than 10~4 M. The signal shows strong concentration dependence on the chiral species as has already been observed in ICD for n -* IT* transitions [5]. Taking into account the second absorp- tion band of azulene in this region, the new CD band seems to originate from the azulene chromophore. The CD band is characteristic of the system (+)-nopmone plus azulene, and accordingly is the ICD of the second TT -* w* absorption band of azulene, which is assigned to the ^i - ^ transition [12 14]. The shorter wave- length side of the ICD band is hidden behind the strong background of the natural CD of (+)-nopuione. In the ICD band, the sharp peak at 347 run is con- sidered to be the 0 <- 0 band of the second ir -* TT* tran- sition of azulene. The 0 <- 0 band at 353 nm in the UV spectrum is well established from fluorescence studies of the second ir -> ir* transition of azulene [15 17]. A small displacement of the 0 *- 0 band is due to the CD background of(+)-nopinone. The two peaks in the longer wavelength region in the ICD band seem to be due to hot bands. From inspection of the UV spectrum, we also see slight shoulders in the wavelength region longer than 353 nm. The UV and ICD data are sum- marized m table 1. For comparison, the magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) spectrum of the second band of azulene is shown in fig. 3, along with the UV spectrum- The ICD spec- trum differs distinctly from the MCD spectrum in its pattern and magnitude. There seems to be no relation- ship between the two. In the wavelength region of 320 240 nm, the CD measurement gives the spectrum in fig. 4 (bottom). The concentration was ca. 5 X 10~5 M for azulene and ca. 5.0 X 10~2 M for nopinone. The strong CD band with its maximum at 292 nm with [ff] 2.69 X 106 has its origin mainly in (+)-nopinone +. The band shape is similar to the CD spectral shape in fig. 1, except for a shoulder at 268 run. The CD spectrum is redrawn re- ferring to the (+)-nopinone, and the difference of the Using the concentration of (+)-nopmone, the maximum |ei value at 292 nm is 2.78 X 103 in Fig. 4, while that at 292 nm is 2 68 X 103 in fig. 1. 23 Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 February 1980 Table 1 The UV and ICD spectral data ofazulene m cyclohe-xane UV ICD -Snax <"'") "max X 10-3 (cm-') ^^ (mn) v^ X 10-3 (cm-1) [0] 353 341 337 3265 323 3155 28.3 29.3 296 306 31 0 31.7 379 362 347 26.4 276 288 0.32 X 103 0 84 X 103 1 03 X 103 296 337 294 340 +3.2 X 106 280 35 7 279 (sh.) 35.8 -12.0 X 106 275 363 273 366 -18 0 X 106 271 369 - - - [o^xio o 24 intensity at each wavelength is plotted to give fig. 4 (top). The difference CD is considered to be the ICD of the third absorption band of azulene. The ICD spec- trum shows sign alternation, but the peaks and troughs seem to correspond to the UV absorption maxima. The UV and ICD spectral data are summarized in table 1. The longest wavelength ICD band at 304 nm is uncer- tain as to its origin. The MCD spectrum in fig. 5 shows negative bands in this region without any alternation of sign. Here again no relationship between the ICD and MCD spectra seems to exist. No ICD has been observed for the first absorption band of azulene. From the UV spectrum the center of gravity of the first -IT -* IT* absorption band is at about 17000 cm"1 for azulene and at 35000 cm^for the n ~> ir* of nopinone. The energy difference (18000 cm"1 between the two excited states, which is the denomi- nator in the perturbation treatment for induced optical activity, seems to be large enough to decrease the in- duced rotational strength [18 20] inazulene. In conclusion, ICD has been observed for the is - IT* transitions of azulene. No direct relationship between the ICD and MCD spectra is present for the IT -* is* band as well as for the n -> v* band [9] . A probable explana- F g. 3. The UV (bottom) and MCD (top) spectra of azulene in cyclohexane at room temperature. Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 Febiuaiy 1980 200 2i0 280 320 a-(nrn) Fig. 4. Induced circular dichroism ofazulene (5.0 X 10~5 M) and (+)-nopmone (5.0 X 10"2 M) in cyclohexane at loom tetnperatuie- os I- i tion of the [CD originates from theoretical work of Schipper [18 20] for the case where the achiral species and chiral species are assumed to be completely disso- ciated in an achiral solvent, but coupled to each other by long-range van der Waab or dispersion forces. For the system treated here, however, a weak charge-transfer force seems to be possible. In fact, a preliminary 1GO MHz PMR measurement ofazulene and (+)-nopmone in cyclohexane-d^ shows a downfield shift, ca. 0-2 ppm, for the protons on the seven-membered ring of azulene- This suggests a weak interaction between azulene and the carbonyl moiety in (+)-nopinone, at least at high concentration (5.0 X 10-1 M for nopinone, 1.9 X IO-1 M for azulene). HM 0 Further studies of the ICD of the IT -> ir* transitions are being carried out using different solvents and chiral species. Acknowledgement The authors are very grateful to Professor A. Yoshikoshi for his kindness in giving us (+)-nopinone. Fig. 5. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The π→π* absorption bands of azulene show circular dichroism in the presence of (+)-nopinone.
